title: 1 — Speaking in a Meeting
situation: I shared my idea in a team meeting. Some people picked up their phones and no one responded right away.
automaticThought: They ignored me; my idea was useless.
evidenceFor: No one immediately supported or praised it, and a few people were looking at their phones.
evidenceAgainst: Later, a colleague appreciated my point; that same person often checks their phone during meetings.
alternativeThought: They might have been busy or replying to something important; my idea could still be useful, and I can follow up later.
note: Next time, I will send a short summary of my main point by email.

title: 2 — Friend Not Replying
situation: I sent my friend a sensitive message, but they did not reply right away.
automaticThought: They are upset with me or no longer like me.
evidenceFor: They still haven’t replied, and recently they have been replying late.
evidenceAgainst: They are often busy and usually apologize later for replying late.
alternativeThought: They might be busy or away from their phone; I can stay calm and check in later.
note: If I don’t hear back in 48 hours, I will gently follow up.

title: 3 — Fear of Giving a Presentation
situation: I have to give a presentation next week and I feel very anxious.
automaticThought: I will fail badly while speaking; people will think I am stupid.
evidenceFor: Last time my voice shook and I didn’t feel fully confident.
evidenceAgainst: I have prepared well; my colleagues helped me practice and the feedback was positive.
alternativeThought: Some nervousness is normal; with practice I can do better, and this is a learning experience.
note: I will rehearse and practice once with a friend.

title: 4 — Family Criticism
situation: My family criticized my career decision and spoke negatively about it.
automaticThought: My decision is wrong; I will fail.
evidenceFor: They used harsh words and argued with me.
evidenceAgainst: Some family members have supported me before; I have planned carefully and I have backup options.
alternativeThought: This reflects their worry and viewpoint; I have reasons and a plan, and I can adjust my decision with full information.
note: They are expressing concern — I will listen calmly and explain my plan.

title: 5 — Frustration About Fitness Efforts
situation: I have been exercising and dieting for a month, but my weight has not gone down.
automaticThought: My efforts are useless; I will never succeed.
evidenceFor: The number on the scale changed very little, and I feel discouraged.
evidenceAgainst: My energy and stamina have improved; my clothes feel different; weight loss varies from person to person.
alternativeThought: Progress is not measured only by the scale; I can focus on small goals and adjust my strategy.
note: I will track my habits, get brief advice from a nutritionist, and set a two-week goal.
